intro: Mentha merdinah, commonly known as the Persian mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are covered in fine hairs. Its small, tubular flowers are usually violet or blue, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. Mentha merdinah is valued for its aromatic properties and has been traditionally used in herbal medicine for its purported cooling and digestive benefits.
